root.name: > The Making of a Global World

5.name: > End of Bretton Woods and Globalisation

6.name: War between Axis (Germany, Japan, Italy) and Allies (Britain, US, Soviet Union)
60 million killed (3% of world population), mostly civilians
Crucial Influence: US emerges as dominant power; Dominance of Soviet Union

7.name: Lesson 1: Mass production needs Mass consumption (requires high-wage incomes and full employment)
Lesson 2: Governments must intervene (control flows of goods/capital/labour) to ensure stability

8.name: Goal: Preserve economic stability and full employment
International Monetary Fund (IMF): Deal with external surpluses/deficits
System: Fixed exchange rate (national currencies pegged to dollar)
Dollar anchored to gold ($35 per ounce)

9.name: Unprecedented growth for Western nations and Japan (1950–1970)
Worldwide spread of technology and enterprise

10.name: Former colonies became independent (poverty, lack of resources)
IMF/World Bank shifted attention to developing countries (late 1950s)
Developing nations organised as Group of 77 (G-77)
NIEO Goal: Control over natural resources, fairer prices, better market access
MNCs: Spread worldwide (1960s/70s) due to high tariffs

11.name: 1960s: Rising US costs weakened finances/competitive strength
US dollar lost confidence (could not maintain gold value)
Collapse of fixed exchange rates (shift to floating rates)
1970s: Developing countries forced to borrow from commercial banks (periodic debt crises)
MNCs shifted production to low-wage Asian countries (e.g., China)
Low-cost Chinese economy became attractive investment destination
